intro: Carex diandra var. prairea, commonly known as prairie sedge, is a perennial grass-like plant native to North America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family and is characterized by its triangular, grass-like leaves and spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in moist to wet habitats such as marshes, wetlands, and prairies. It has fibrous roots and produces small, wind-pollinated flowers. Its structure and growth habits make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
